title: Grades 6-8: American Sign Language, Level III
subject: Languages Other Than English (2014-)

document.title: Texas Essential Knowledge and Skills for Languages Other Than English

EF3693A7A88346B680D8369F19CB8C8E.description: show evidence of becoming a lifelong learner by using ASL at the intermediate proficiency level for personal enrichment and career development.

D6426D44A76642BEA6A130D00DE24D3A.description: use technology to communicate with the Deaf/ASL community; and

29DE0EE2B74D4CCE9FA183B0FAEF40D1.description: apply ASL at the intermediate proficiency level in or out of the school setting through involvement in cultural activities such as attending Deaf events;

C77C216851314DA4B6AE8F1FCEFD6CC4.description: Communities. The student participates in the Deaf/ASL community by using ASL. The student is expected to:

7FDE7A1AE9F643C19A3575CE051FF144.description: apply ASL at the intermediate proficiency level to demonstrate an understanding of how one language and culture can influence another.

8A233EAEF0B24334B1754A50FFB49D60.description: apply ASL at the intermediate proficiency level to demonstrate an understanding of the nature of culture through comparisons of the student's own culture and the American Deaf culture; and

8C5CC91F07E4428594A49DA14B96FD63.description: apply ASL at the intermediate proficiency level to demonstrate an understanding of the nature of language through comparisons of the student's own language and ASL;

8F652546A92942C48AFE7A9AA59F6501.description: Comparisons. The student expands insight into the nature of language and culture by comparing the student's own language and culture to ASL and American Deaf culture. The student is expected to:

013FE705CCBE44B2800C8591069ECBD4.description: apply ASL at the intermediate proficiency level to obtain, reinforce, or expand knowledge of other subject areas.

7451F5FAD9874EE5BFFD6359FC027A78.description: use resources and digital technology to gain access to in-depth information about ASL and Deaf culture; and

4DE6CCCD438849C0A61F38BA52F35DB7.description: Connections. The student uses ASL to make connections with other subject areas and to acquire information. The student is expected to:

E10695F03F924E35B7A2DF67A89A8E52.description: demonstrate an in-depth understanding of Deaf history and how it applies to the perspectives of American Deaf culture.

8A6D5C0B4E684172A261A3D56F185F53.description: apply ASL to show evidence of appreciation of the contributions to arts and sciences by the Deaf and how they are applied to the perspectives of American Deaf culture; and

34010B47173647F691B148CA0F7A5AE5.description: apply ASL to show evidence of appreciation of ASL literature created by the Deaf and how it applies to the perspectives of American Deaf culture;

2279A28E70F54E438719417916875F93.description: apply ASL to recognize and use Deaf cultural norms to demonstrate an understanding of the perspectives of American Deaf culture;

B7E6F60B1D654CC0B33A1F5159C5D109.description: Cultures. The student gains knowledge and understanding of American Deaf culture. The student is expected to:

1626742EB796479E99F129982682CC4C.description: create and express ASL literature, including handshape stories, that follows traditional cultural features.

22F249529F744C4D9FAEE2DA7DC5A403.description: demonstrate appropriate usage of ASL phonology, morphology, syntax, semantics, and pragmatics at the intermediate proficiency level; and

94CD71306B094CFAA1C9369BC0847269.description: convey information in ASL using concepts, classifiers, phrases, and sentences to others without voice at the intermediate proficiency level;

5E4A0366FC974BBE966729F53A2B0110.description: demonstrate an understanding of ASL such as stories, commands, and instructions when dealing with familiar and less familiar topics;

EDF1752C5A47476AA457D8115DF8307D.description: engage in a variety of ASL exchanges of learned material to socialize and to provide and obtain information at an intermediate proficiency level;

79917F0539AB45E2BF7E16E7B70EF97F.description: Communication. The student communicates in ASL using expressive and receptive communication skills without voice. The student is expected to:
